subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the next figure in the sequence.

Fig 1: Hexagon at 0deg, small circle inside
Fig 2: Hexagon at 45deg, small triangle inside
Fig 3: Hexagon at 90deg, small square inside
Fig 4: Hexagon at 135deg, small circle inside
Fig 5: ?
options: A: Hexagon at 180deg, small triangle inside
B: Hexagon at 135deg, small circle inside
C: Hexagon at 180deg, small square inside
D: Hexagon at 0deg, small triangle inside
E: Hexagon at 90deg, small triangle inside

explanation: Two independent patterns operate simultaneously: (1) The hexagon rotates 45 degrees clockwise each step (0->45->90->135->180). (2) The inner shape cycles through circle->triangle->square->circle->triangle. Following both rules: hexagon at 180deg with triangle inside.

hints.text: Look for TWO patterns changing independently.
Track the outer hexagon rotation AND the inner shape sequence separately.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the next figure in the sequence.

Fig 1: Large white pentagon, 1 dot below
Fig 2: Medium grey pentagon, 2 dots below
Fig 3: Small black pentagon, 3 dots below
Fig 4: Large white pentagon, 4 dots below
Fig 5: ?
options: A: Medium grey pentagon, 5 dots below
B: Small black pentagon, 5 dots below
C: Medium grey pentagon, 1 dot below
D: Large black pentagon, 5 dots below
E: Small white pentagon, 5 dots below

explanation: Three patterns operate: (1) Size cycles: large->medium->small->large->medium. (2) Fill cycles: white->grey->black->white->grey. (3) Dots increment: 1->2->3->4->5. The answer is medium grey pentagon with 5 dots.

hints.text: There are THREE attributes changing. Track each one.
Size and fill both cycle through 3 states. Dots simply count up.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the next figure in the sequence.

Fig 1: Rectangle with diagonal line from top-left to bottom-right
Fig 2: Rectangle with diagonal line from top-right to bottom-left
Fig 3: Rectangle with horizontal line through middle
Fig 4: Rectangle with vertical line through middle
Fig 5: ?
options: A: Rectangle with diagonal line from top-left to bottom-right
D: Rectangle with diagonal line from top-right to bottom-left
E: Rectangle with two horizontal lines

explanation: The internal line rotates through 4 positions: diagonal (TL-BR) -> diagonal (TR-BL) -> horizontal -> vertical -> back to diagonal (TL-BR). This is a 4-step cycle, so position 5 returns to the first pattern.

hints.text: Focus on how the line inside the rectangle changes orientation.
The line cycles through 4 different orientations, then repeats.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the next figure in the sequence.

Fig 1: Square outline, arrow pointing UP inside
Fig 2: Square outline, arrow pointing RIGHT inside, small dot in top-left corner
Fig 3: Square outline, arrow pointing DOWN inside, small dots in top-left and top-right corners
Fig 4: Square outline, arrow pointing LEFT inside, small dots in top-left, top-right, and bottom-right corners
Fig 5: ?
options: A: Square outline, arrow pointing UP inside, dots in all 4 corners
B: Square outline, arrow pointing RIGHT inside, dots in all 4 corners
C: Square outline, arrow pointing UP inside, no dots
D: Square outline, arrow pointing DOWN inside, dots in all 4 corners
E: Square outline, arrow pointing UP inside, dot in top-left only

explanation: Two patterns: (1) Arrow rotates 90deg clockwise each step: UP->RIGHT->DOWN->LEFT->UP. (2) Dots accumulate in corners clockwise: 0->1->2->3->4 dots. Fig 5 has arrow pointing UP with all 4 corners filled.

hints.text: Track the arrow direction AND the corner dots separately.
Arrow rotates 90deg each time. Dots add one per step in clockwise order.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the next figure in the sequence.

Fig 1: Black circle on left, white triangle on right, line above both
Fig 2: White circle on left, black triangle on right, line below both
Fig 3: Black circle on left, white triangle on right, line above both
Fig 4: White circle on left, black triangle on right, line below both
Fig 5: ?
options: A: Black circle on left, white triangle on right, line above both
B: White circle on left, white triangle on right, line above both
C: Black circle on right, white triangle on left, line above both
D: Black triangle on left, white circle on right, line above both
E: White circle on left, black triangle on right, line above both

explanation: The pattern alternates between two states: State A (black circle, white triangle, line above) and State B (white circle, black triangle, line below). Odd positions show State A, even positions show State B. Position 5 is odd, so State A.

hints.text: Compare figures 1 and 3, then figures 2 and 4. What do you notice?
The entire configuration alternates between two complete states.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the next figure in the sequence.

Fig 1: Pentagon with 1 side bold
Fig 2: Pentagon with 2 adjacent sides bold
Fig 3: Pentagon with 3 adjacent sides bold
Fig 4: Pentagon with 4 adjacent sides bold
Fig 5: ?
options: A: Pentagon with all 5 sides bold
B: Pentagon with no sides bold
E: Pentagon with 4 non-adjacent sides bold

explanation: The number of bold sides increases by 1 each step, and they are always adjacent. Following 1->2->3->4->5, all 5 sides should be bold.

hints.text: Count the bold sides in each figure.
Bold sides increase by 1 each step, staying adjacent.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the next figure in the sequence.

Fig 1: Large outer circle, small inner square, arrow pointing outward from center-top
Fig 2: Large outer square, small inner circle, arrow pointing outward from center-right
Fig 3: Large outer circle, small inner square, arrow pointing outward from center-bottom
Fig 4: Large outer square, small inner circle, arrow pointing outward from center-left
Fig 5: ?
options: A: Large outer circle, small inner square, arrow pointing outward from center-top
B: Large outer circle, small inner circle, arrow pointing outward from center-top
C: Large outer square, small inner square, arrow pointing outward from center-top
D: Large outer circle, small inner square, arrow pointing outward from center-right
E: Large outer square, small inner circle, arrow pointing outward from center-top

explanation: Three independent patterns: (1) Outer shape alternates circle/square - position 5 is circle. (2) Inner shape alternates square/circle - position 5 is square. (3) Arrow rotates 90deg clockwise: top->right->bottom->left->top.

hints.text: Track outer shape, inner shape, and arrow direction separately.
Outer and inner shapes alternate. Arrow rotates clockwise.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the next figure in the sequence.

Fig 1: Triangle pointing up
Fig 2: Triangle pointing right
Fig 3: Triangle pointing down
Fig 4: Triangle pointing left
Fig 5: ?

explanation: The triangle rotates 90 degrees clockwise each step. After pointing up, right, down, left, it returns to pointing up - completing the cycle.

hints.text: Which direction is the triangle rotating?
90 degrees clockwise each step - what comes after left?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the next figure in the sequence.

Fig 1: 3x3 grid with black square in position 1 (top-left)
Fig 2: 3x3 grid with black squares in positions 1 and 2
Fig 3: 3x3 grid with black squares in positions 1, 2, and 3
Fig 4: 3x3 grid with black squares in positions 2, 3, and 4
Fig 5: ?
options: A: 3x3 grid with black squares in positions 3, 4, and 5
B: 3x3 grid with black squares in positions 1, 2, 3, and 4
C: 3x3 grid with black squares in positions 4, 5, and 6
D: 3x3 grid with black squares in positions 2, 3, 4, and 5
E: 3x3 grid with black squares in positions 3, 4, 5, and 6

context.rule: 3-cell window slides one position each step

explanation: A 'window' of 3 consecutive black squares slides through the grid. Fig 1: [1], Fig 2: [1,2], Fig 3: [1,2,3], Fig 4: [2,3,4]. The window maintains 3 cells but shifts position. Fig 5: [3,4,5].

hints.text: The black squares form a connected group that moves.
Watch which squares are added and removed each step.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the next figure in the sequence.

Fig 1: Circle divided into 4 quarters - top-left black, rest white
Fig 2: Circle divided into 4 quarters - top-right black, rest white
Fig 3: Circle divided into 4 quarters - bottom-right black, rest white
Fig 4: Circle divided into 4 quarters - bottom-left black, rest white
Fig 5: ?
options: A: Circle divided into 4 quarters - top-left black, rest white
B: Circle divided into 4 quarters - all white
C: Circle divided into 4 quarters - top-left and top-right black
D: Circle divided into 4 quarters - bottom-left black, rest white
E: Square divided into 4 quarters - top-left black

explanation: The single black quarter moves clockwise around the circle: top-left -> top-right -> bottom-right -> bottom-left -> top-left. Position 5 returns to top-left.

hints.text: Track where the black quarter is in each figure.
The black quarter moves clockwise. What comes after bottom-left?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which figure is the odd one out?

A: Square with circle inside, both black outline
B: Triangle with triangle inside, both black outline
C: Pentagon with pentagon inside, both black outline
D: Hexagon with square inside, both black outline
E: Circle with circle inside, both black outline

context.odd_one: D - inner shape different from outer

explanation: In A, B, C, and E, the inner shape is the same type as the outer shape (square-square, triangle-triangle, etc.). Only D has mismatched shapes: hexagon outside, square inside.

hints.text: Compare the outer and inner shapes in each figure.
Most figures have matching inner and outer shapes.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which figure is the odd one out?

A: Large black circle, small white square at top-right
B: Large black triangle, small white circle at top-right
C: Large black square, small white triangle at top-right
D: Large black pentagon, small white hexagon at bottom-left
E: Large black hexagon, small white pentagon at top-right

context.odd_one: D - small shape at bottom-left instead of top-right

explanation: All figures have a large black shape and small white shape. In A, B, C, E the small shape is at top-right. Only D has the small shape at bottom-left - a position difference.

hints.text: Look at both the shapes AND their positions.
Where is the small shape positioned in each figure?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which figure is the odd one out?

A: Arrow pointing right, 3 dots below, shaded grey
B: Arrow pointing up, 4 dots below, shaded grey
C: Arrow pointing left, 5 dots below, shaded grey
D: Arrow pointing down, 6 dots below, shaded grey
E: Arrow pointing right, 8 dots below, shaded grey

context.odd_one: E - should have 7 dots but has 8

explanation: The figures show 3, 4, 5, 6, 8 dots. The sequence should be consecutive: 3, 4, 5, 6, 7. Figure E has 8 dots instead of 7, breaking the +1 increment pattern.

hints.text: Count the dots in each figure.
Is there a numerical pattern in the dot counts?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which figure is the odd one out?

A: Black square rotated 45deg (diamond orientation)
B: Black triangle rotated 60deg
C: Black pentagon rotated 36deg
D: Black hexagon rotated 30deg
E: Black circle

context.odd_one: E - circle has no rotational reference (infinite symmetry)

explanation: Each polygon is rotated by half its rotational symmetry angle (360/n/2). Square: 45deg, Triangle: 60deg, Pentagon: 36deg, Hexagon: 30deg. A circle has infinite rotational symmetry - no specific rotation angle applies.

hints.text: Consider the relationship between sides and rotation.
How does the number of sides affect rotation symmetry?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which figure is the odd one out?

A: Rectangle divided vertically - left half has horizontal stripes, right half is black
B: Circle divided vertically - left half has vertical stripes, right half is white
C: Triangle divided vertically - left half has diagonal stripes, right half is grey
D: Hexagon divided vertically - left half has dots, right half is black
E: Pentagon divided vertically - left half has crosshatch, right half is white

context.odd_one: B - only one where stripe direction matches division direction (both vertical)

explanation: In A, C, D, E, the stripe/pattern direction differs from the division direction. Only in B are both vertical - the vertical stripes match the vertical division line. This creates visual redundancy unlike the others.

hints.text: Look at the direction of patterns in the left half.
How does the pattern direction relate to how the shape is divided?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which figure is the odd one out?

A: Three overlapping circles
B: Three overlapping squares
C: Three overlapping triangles
D: Two overlapping pentagons
E: Three overlapping hexagons

context.odd_one: D - only has 2 shapes instead of 3

explanation: Figures A, B, C, and E all show THREE overlapping shapes. Only D shows TWO overlapping shapes, making it the odd one out based on quantity.

hints.text: Count the number of shapes in each figure.
How many shapes overlap in each figure?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which figure is the odd one out?

A: Large white square containing small black circle at center
B: Large white circle containing small black square at center
C: Large white triangle containing small black triangle at center
D: Large white hexagon containing small black circle at center
E: Large white pentagon containing small black square at center

context.odd_one: C - both outer and inner are triangles (same number of sides)

explanation: In A, B, D, E the inner and outer shapes have different numbers of sides (or one is a circle). Only in C are both shapes triangles - matching side counts. The rule is that inner and outer should differ.

hints.text: Compare the types of inner and outer shapes.
In most figures, the inner shape differs from the outer. Which doesn't?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which figure is the odd one out?

A: Arrow pointing NE with tail at SW
B: Arrow pointing SE with tail at NW
C: Arrow pointing NW with tail at SE
D: Arrow pointing SW with tail at NE
E: Arrow pointing E with tail at W

explanation: Arrows A, B, C, D all point in diagonal directions (NE, SE, NW, SW). Only arrow E points in a cardinal direction (East). The common property is diagonal orientation.

hints.text: Consider the direction each arrow points.
Are they pointing diagonally or along horizontal/vertical?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Complete the analogy:

[Large black square with white circle inside] is to [Small white square with black circle inside]
as
[Large black triangle with white star inside] is to [?]
options: A: Small white triangle with black star inside
B: Large white triangle with black star inside
C: Small black triangle with white star inside
D: Small white square with black star inside
E: Small white triangle with white star inside

explanation: Two transformations occur: (1) Size decreases from large to small. (2) All fills invert: black becomes white, white becomes black. Applying both: Large black triangle with white star becomes Small white triangle with black star.

hints.text: What changes between the first pair?
Both size AND color/fill change. Apply both rules.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Complete the analogy:

[Pentagon rotated 0deg, 3 dots inside arranged in triangle] is to [Pentagon rotated 72deg, 3 dots inside arranged in line]
as
[Hexagon rotated 0deg, 4 dots inside arranged in square] is to [?]
options: A: Hexagon rotated 60deg, 4 dots inside arranged in line
B: Hexagon rotated 72deg, 4 dots inside arranged in line
C: Hexagon rotated 60deg, 4 dots inside arranged in diamond
D: Pentagon rotated 60deg, 4 dots inside arranged in line
E: Hexagon rotated 90deg, 4 dots inside arranged in line

explanation: Two transformations: (1) Rotate shape by its internal angle (pentagon: 72deg, hexagon: 60deg). (2) Rearrange dots from a 2D pattern to a line. Hexagon rotates 60deg and dots form a line.

hints.text: The rotation amount relates to the shape's geometry.
Pentagon rotates 72deg (its internal angle). What's the hexagon's internal angle?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Complete the analogy:

[Circle divided into 2 equal parts: left black, right white] is to [Circle divided into 4 equal parts: alternating black-white]
as
[Square divided into 2 equal parts: top black, bottom white] is to [?]
options: A: Square divided into 4 equal parts: alternating black-white in checkerboard
B: Square divided into 4 equal parts: top two black, bottom two white
C: Square divided into 8 equal parts
D: Rectangle divided into 4 equal parts
E: Square divided into 4 equal parts: all white

explanation: The transformation doubles the number of divisions and applies alternating fills. Circle goes from 2 parts to 4 with alternating colors. Square should go from 2 parts to 4 in a checkerboard pattern.

hints.text: How does the number of divisions change?
Divisions double, and the fill pattern alternates.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Complete the analogy:

[Arrow pointing UP with circle at tip] is to [Arrow pointing DOWN with circle at tail]
as
[Arrow pointing LEFT with square at tip] is to [?]
options: A: Arrow pointing RIGHT with square at tail
B: Arrow pointing RIGHT with square at tip
C: Arrow pointing LEFT with square at tail
D: Arrow pointing DOWN with square at tail
E: Arrow pointing UP with circle at tail

explanation: Two changes: (1) Arrow direction reverses 180 degrees (UP to DOWN, LEFT to RIGHT). (2) The attached shape moves from tip to tail. Applying both: LEFT becomes RIGHT, square moves from tip to tail.

hints.text: What happens to the arrow direction?
The arrow flips AND the shape moves from one end to the other.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Complete the analogy:

[3 shapes in row: circle, square, triangle - all white] is to [3 shapes in row: triangle, circle, square - all black]
as
[3 shapes in column: star, hexagon, diamond - all grey] is to [?]
options: A: 3 shapes in column: diamond, star, hexagon - all striped
B: 3 shapes in row: diamond, star, hexagon - all striped
C: 3 shapes in column: hexagon, diamond, star - all white
D: 3 shapes in column: diamond, star, hexagon - all white
E: 3 shapes in row: star, hexagon, diamond - all striped

explanation: Two transformations: (1) Shapes rotate in sequence - first becomes last, others shift. (2) Fill changes to next in progression (white->black, grey->striped). Layout (row/column) stays same.

hints.text: How does the order of shapes change?
Shapes shift positions AND fill changes. Row/column orientation stays.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Complete the analogy:

[Single line] is to [Two parallel lines]
as
[Single triangle] is to [?]
options: A: Two triangles side by side
C: Triangle with line through it

explanation: The relationship is simple duplication: one element becomes two of the same element arranged parallel/side by side. One line becomes two lines, so one triangle becomes two triangles.

hints.text: What happened to the single line?
One became two. Apply the same change to the triangle.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Complete the analogy:

[Square frame with diagonal cross inside] is to [Circle frame with plus sign inside]
as
[Triangle frame with Y-shape inside] is to [?]
options: A: Diamond frame with X-shape inside
B: Hexagon frame with asterisk inside
C: Pentagon frame with star inside
D: Circle frame with Y-shape inside
E: Square frame with T-shape inside

explanation: The transformation: (1) Outer shape gains sides (4-sided square to circle/many sides, 3-sided triangle to 6-sided hexagon). (2) Inner pattern changes but maintains line-based nature. Triangle frame with Y becomes hexagon frame with asterisk.

hints.text: How does the outer shape change in the first pair?
The outer shape's sides increase significantly.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Complete the analogy:

[Full circle] is to [Half circle (semicircle)]
as
[Full square] is to [?]
options: A: Half square (rectangle, half the width)

explanation: The relationship is bisection: a full shape becomes half. Full circle becomes semicircle (half), so full square becomes half a square - a rectangle with half the area, maintaining one dimension.

hints.text: What fraction of the circle is shown in the second figure?
Half. What does half a square look like?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the missing figure in the 3x3 matrix.

Row 1: [Circle, 1 dot] [Circle, 2 dots] [Circle, 3 dots]
Row 2: [Square, 2 dots] [Square, 3 dots] [Square, 4 dots]
Row 3: [Triangle, 3 dots] [Triangle, 4 dots] [?]

explanation: Row rule: dots increase by 1 across each row. Row 3: 3->4->5 dots. Column rule: shape stays the same within each row. Row 3 has triangles. Answer: Triangle with 5 dots.

hints.text: Look at each row separately. How do the dots change?
Dots increase by 1 in each row. Row 3 goes 3, 4, ?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the missing figure in the 3x3 matrix.

Row 1: [Black square] [White square] [Grey square]
Row 2: [White circle] [Grey circle] [Black circle]
Row 3: [Grey triangle] [Black triangle] [?]

explanation: Each row must contain black, white, and grey (all three fills). Row 3 has grey and black, missing white. Each column must have all shapes, but the key constraint is the fill pattern. Answer: White triangle.

hints.text: What fills appear in each row?
Each row needs all three fills. Row 3 has grey and black - what's missing?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the missing figure in the 3x3 matrix.

Row 1: [Circle+Square overlay] [Square only] [Circle only]
Row 2: [Triangle+Circle overlay] [Circle only] [Triangle only]
Row 3: [Square+Triangle overlay] [Triangle only] [?]

explanation: The rule is subtraction: Column 1 shape overlay minus Column 2 shape equals Column 3. Row 3: (Square+Triangle) - Triangle = Square. The missing figure is Square only.

hints.text: Look at how columns relate to each other.
Column 1 minus Column 2 equals Column 3 (shape removal).

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the missing figure in the 3x3 matrix.

Row 1: [Arrow UP] [Arrow RIGHT] [Arrow DOWN]
Row 2: [Arrow RIGHT] [Arrow DOWN] [Arrow LEFT]
Row 3: [Arrow DOWN] [Arrow LEFT] [?]

explanation: In each row, arrows rotate 90deg clockwise: UP->RIGHT->DOWN, RIGHT->DOWN->LEFT, DOWN->LEFT->UP. Row 3 continues: DOWN, LEFT, UP. Missing figure is Arrow UP.

hints.text: How does the arrow direction change across each row?
Arrows rotate 90 degrees clockwise in each row.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the missing figure in the 3x3 matrix.

Row 1: [Large circle, no line] [Medium circle, 1 line through] [Small circle, 2 lines through]
Row 2: [Large square, 1 line through] [Medium square, 2 lines through] [Small square, no line]
Row 3: [Large triangle, 2 lines through] [Medium triangle, no line] [?]

explanation: Size decreases across rows: Large->Medium->Small. Each row contains 0, 1, and 2 lines (in different orders). Row 3 has 2 and 0 lines shown, missing 1 line. Answer: Small triangle with 1 line.

hints.text: Track both size and number of lines separately.
Each row has 0, 1, 2 lines somewhere. What's missing in row 3?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Find the missing figure in the 3x3 matrix.

Row 1: [1 star] [2 stars] [3 stars]
Row 2: [2 stars] [4 stars] [6 stars]
Row 3: [3 stars] [6 stars] [?]

explanation: The matrix follows multiplication: Row N, Column M = N x M. Row 3, Column 3 = 3 x 3 = 9 stars. This creates the standard multiplication table pattern.

hints.text: Look at the numbers: 1,2,3 / 2,4,6 / 3,6,?
It's a multiplication table. Row 3 x Column 3 = ?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which option shows this figure rotated 180 degrees?

Original: Letter 'R' with a small circle at bottom-left corner
options: A: Upside-down R with circle at top-right
B: Backwards R with circle at bottom-right
C: Normal R with circle at top-left
D: Upside-down backwards R with circle at bottom-left
E: Upside-down R with circle at bottom-right

explanation: 180-degree rotation flips everything upside down and reverses left-right. The R becomes upside down, and the circle moves from bottom-left to top-right (diagonally opposite).

hints.text: 180 degrees means turning completely upside down.
Track both the letter orientation AND where the circle moves to.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which option shows this figure rotated 270 degrees clockwise?

Original: Square with arrow pointing UP from center, dot in top-right corner
options: A: Square with arrow pointing LEFT, dot in top-left corner
B: Square with arrow pointing RIGHT, dot in bottom-right corner
C: Square with arrow pointing DOWN, dot in bottom-left corner
D: Square with arrow pointing LEFT, dot in bottom-left corner
E: Square with arrow pointing UP, dot in bottom-right corner

explanation: 270 degrees clockwise = 90 degrees counterclockwise. Arrow pointing UP rotates to point LEFT. Dot in top-right moves to top-left (each corner shifts counterclockwise one position).

hints.text: 270 clockwise is the same as 90 counterclockwise.
UP becomes LEFT. Track where the corner dot moves.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which option shows this figure rotated 90 degrees clockwise?

Original: T-shape lying on its side (horizontal bar on left, vertical bar extending right)
options: A: T-shape with horizontal bar on top, vertical bar extending down
B: T-shape with horizontal bar on bottom, vertical bar extending up
C: T-shape with horizontal bar on right, vertical bar extending left

explanation: 90 degrees clockwise: the horizontal bar (on left) rotates to be on top, and the vertical bar (extending right) now extends down. This creates an upright T shape with bar on top.

hints.text: Imagine turning the page 90 degrees to the right.
What was on the left goes to the top.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which option shows this figure rotated 135 degrees clockwise?

Original: Plus sign (+) with the top arm shaded black
options: A: Plus sign with top-right arm shaded black
B: Plus sign with right arm shaded black
C: Plus sign with bottom-right arm shaded (X orientation with NE arm black)
D: Plus sign with bottom arm shaded black
E: Plus sign with left arm shaded black

explanation: 135 degrees = 90 + 45. The plus sign rotates to become an X shape. The top arm (at 0 degrees) moves to 135 degrees position, which is the bottom-right diagonal (or NE arm of the X when viewed as such).

hints.text: 135 degrees turns a + into an X orientation.
Track where the shaded arm moves: 0 degrees + 135 degrees = 135 degrees position.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which option shows this figure rotated 90 degrees anticlockwise?

Original: Flag shape - rectangle with triangular point on right side, pointing right
options: D: Flag pointing right (same as original)

explanation: 90 degrees anticlockwise (counterclockwise): what was pointing right now points up. The flag rotates so its point faces upward.

hints.text: Anticlockwise is the opposite of clock hands.
Right becomes up when rotating counterclockwise.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which option shows the reflection of this figure in a HORIZONTAL mirror line (placed below the figure)?

Original: Triangle pointing UP with a small square in the top corner
options: A: Triangle pointing DOWN with square in bottom corner
B: Triangle pointing UP with square in bottom corner
C: Triangle pointing DOWN with square in top corner
D: Triangle pointing LEFT with square on right

explanation: Horizontal mirror line flips the figure vertically (top becomes bottom). Triangle pointing UP becomes triangle pointing DOWN. Square at top moves to bottom position.

hints.text: A horizontal mirror flips things upside down.
Top becomes bottom, but left-right stays the same.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which option shows the reflection of this figure in a DIAGONAL mirror line (going from top-left to bottom-right)?

Original: Letter 'L' shape - vertical bar on left, horizontal bar at bottom extending right
options: A: L rotated - horizontal bar on top, vertical bar extending down on right
B: Backwards L - vertical bar on right, horizontal bar at bottom extending left
C: Upside-down L - vertical bar on left, horizontal bar at top

explanation: Diagonal mirror (TL-BR) swaps x and y coordinates. The vertical bar (along y-axis) becomes horizontal (along x-axis), and the horizontal bar becomes vertical. The L shape transforms as if rotated and flipped.

hints.text: Diagonal mirrors swap horizontal and vertical.
Imagine folding along the diagonal - where does each part land?

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which option shows the reflection of this figure in a VERTICAL mirror line?

Original: Number '7' with a dot on the left side of the horizontal bar
options: A: Backwards 7 with dot on the right side
B: Upside-down 7 with dot on left
C: Normal 7 with dot on right side
D: Backwards 7 with dot on left side

explanation: Vertical mirror flips left-right. The 7 becomes a backwards 7 (mirrored), and the dot that was on the left side of the bar is now on the right side.

hints.text: Vertical mirror swaps left and right.
The 7 reverses AND the dot position changes.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which option shows BOTH a vertical reflection AND then a horizontal reflection of the original figure?

Original: Arrow pointing to top-right (NE), with circle at the tail
options: A: Arrow pointing to bottom-left (SW), with circle at the tail
B: Arrow pointing to top-left (NW), with circle at the tail
C: Arrow pointing to bottom-right (SE), with circle at the tail
D: Arrow pointing to top-right (NE), with circle at the head
E: Arrow pointing to bottom-left (SW), with circle at the head

explanation: Vertical reflection changes NE to NW. Then horizontal reflection changes NW to SW. Two perpendicular reflections equal a 180-degree rotation. Circle stays at the tail throughout.

hints.text: Apply each reflection in sequence.
Two perpendicular reflections = 180 degree rotation.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Which option shows the reflection of this figure in a vertical mirror line?

Original: Smiley face with winking LEFT eye (left eye closed, right eye open)
options: A: Smiley face with winking RIGHT eye
B: Smiley face with both eyes closed
C: Upside-down smiley face with winking left eye
D: Smiley face with winking LEFT eye (same as original)
E: Sad face with winking right eye

explanation: Vertical mirror swaps left and right. The winking eye was on the left, so in the reflection it appears on the right. The smile stays a smile (horizontal features unchanged).

hints.text: Which side is the winking eye on?
Left-right swap means the winking eye moves to the other side.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Each figure has a two-letter code. Work out the code for the test figure.

Fig 1: Large black circle = AX
Fig 2: Small black circle = BX
Fig 3: Large white circle = AY
Fig 4: Small white square = BY
Test figure: Large white square = ?

explanation: First letter encodes size: A=large, B=small. Second letter encodes fill: X=black, Y=white. Large white square: A (large) + Y (white) = AY. Shape is not encoded in this system.

hints.text: Compare figures with the same letter to find what they share.
First letter = size (A=large, B=small). Second letter = fill.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Each figure has a three-letter code. Work out the code for the test figure.

Fig 1: Large black triangle pointing up = APX
Fig 2: Small white triangle pointing up = BQX
Fig 3: Large black circle = APN
Fig 4: Small white square pointing right = BQY
Test figure: Large white triangle pointing down = ?

explanation: Three-letter code: Position 1 = size (A=large, B=small). Position 2 = fill (P=black, Q=white). Position 3 = direction (X=up, Y=right, Z=down, N=none). Large white triangle pointing down = A+Q+Z = AQZ.

hints.text: Each letter position encodes a different attribute.
Size, then fill, then direction. Match each to find the code.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Each figure has a two-letter code. Work out the code for the test figure.

Fig 1: Circle with 1 dot inside = FA
Fig 2: Square with 2 dots inside = GB
Fig 3: Triangle with 3 dots inside = HC
Fig 4: Circle with 2 dots inside = FB
Test figure: Square with 3 dots inside = ?

explanation: First letter encodes shape: F=circle, G=square, H=triangle. Second letter encodes dot count: A=1, B=2, C=3. Square with 3 dots = G+C = GC.

hints.text: Find figures with the same shape and compare their first letters.
First letter = shape, second letter = number of dots.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Each figure has a code where letters can appear in any order. Work out the code for the test figure.

Fig 1: Black circle with horizontal line through = JM
Fig 2: White square with vertical line through = KN
Fig 3: Black square with vertical line through = JN
Fig 4: White circle with diagonal line through = KP
Test figure: Black circle with diagonal line through = ?

explanation: J/K encodes fill (J=black, K=white). M/N/P encodes line type (M=horizontal, N=vertical, P=diagonal). Shape is NOT encoded. Black circle with diagonal = J+P = JP.

hints.text: Not all attributes have codes. Which attributes ARE encoded?
Fill and line type are encoded. Shape is ignored in this system.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Each figure has a code. Work out the code for the test figure.

Fig 1: Arrow pointing up = 1
Fig 2: Arrow pointing right = 2
Fig 3: Arrow pointing down = 3
Fig 4: Arrow pointing left = 4
Test figure: Arrow pointing up-right (diagonal NE) = ?

explanation: Cardinals have single codes: up=1, right=2, down=3, left=4. Diagonals combine the two adjacent cardinal codes. Up-right (NE) = up(1) + right(2) = 12.

hints.text: Diagonal directions combine two cardinal directions.
NE = North(up) + East(right). Combine their codes.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
Each figure has a two-letter code based on position. Work out the code for the test figure.

Fig 1: Star in top-left corner = TL
Fig 2: Star in bottom-right corner = BR
Fig 3: Star in center = CC
Fig 4: Star in top-right corner = TR
Test figure: Star in bottom-left corner = ?

explanation: First letter = vertical position (T=top, C=center, B=bottom). Second letter = horizontal position (L=left, C=center, R=right). Bottom-left = B+L = BL.

hints.text: The code describes WHERE the star is positioned.
First letter = up/down position, second letter = left/right position.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text: A cube has these faces: TOP=star, FRONT=circle, RIGHT=triangle. If the cube is rotated so the FRONT face becomes the TOP, which shape will be on the new FRONT face?
options: A: The shape that was on BOTTOM

explanation: When tilting forward (front becomes top), the faces cycle: front->top, top->back, back->bottom, bottom->front. So the new front is what was on the bottom.

hints.text: Visualize tilting the cube forward toward you.
The bottom face rotates up to become the new front.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
This net folds into a cube. Which face will be OPPOSITE the star?

Net layout (cross shape):
    [A]
[B][STAR][C][D]
    [E]

explanation: In a cross-shaped net, faces opposite to the center are those that would be two positions away when folded. Face D is in line with the star and will be opposite when folded.

hints.text: Imagine folding the net into a cube.
In a cross net, the center's opposite is at the far end of the horizontal strip.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text:
How many unit cubes are needed to build this 3D shape?

Shape: A staircase with 3 steps - bottom layer has 3 cubes in a row, middle layer has 2 cubes on top of the first 2, top layer has 1 cube on top.

explanation: Count by layers: bottom layer = 3 cubes, middle layer = 2 cubes, top layer = 1 cube. Total = 3 + 2 + 1 = 6 cubes.

hints.text: Count the cubes in each layer separately.
Bottom: 3, Middle: 2, Top: 1. Add them up.

subject: non_verbal_reasoning

content.text: A cube is painted red on all faces, then cut into 27 smaller cubes (3x3x3). How many small cubes have exactly TWO red faces?

explanation: In a 3x3x3 cube: corners (8 cubes) have 3 painted faces, edges (12 cubes) have 2 painted faces, face centers (6 cubes) have 1 painted face, center (1 cube) has 0 painted faces. Answer: 12 edge cubes.

hints.text: Think about where a small cube sits in the big cube.
Edge cubes (not corners) touch exactly 2 outer faces.
